lines.text: Enter the PRINCESS, and her train, a Forester, BOYET, ROSALINE, MARIA, and KATHARINE

lines.speaker: princess
lines.text: Was that the king, that spurred his horse so hard Against the steep uprising of the hill?

lines.speaker: boyet
lines.text: I know not; but I think it was not he.

lines.speaker: princess
lines.text: Whoe'er a' was, a' show'd a mounting mind. Well, lords, to-day we shall have our dispatch: On Saturday we will return to France. Then, forester, my friend, where is the bush That we must stand and play the murderer in?

lines.speaker: forester
lines.text: Hereby, upon the edge of yonder coppice; A stand where you may make the fairest shoot.

lines.speaker: princess
lines.text: I thank my beauty, I am fair that shoot, And thereupon thou speak'st the fairest shoot.

lines.speaker: forester
lines.text: Pardon me, madam, for I meant not so.

lines.speaker: princess
lines.text: What, what? first praise me and again say no? O short-lived pride! Not fair? alack for woe!

lines.speaker: forester
lines.text: Yes, madam, fair.

lines.speaker: princess
lines.text: Nay, never paint me now: Where fair is not, praise cannot mend the brow. Here, good my glass, take this for telling true: Fair payment for foul words is more than due.

lines.speaker: forester
lines.text: Nothing but fair is that which you inherit.

lines.speaker: princess
lines.text: See see, my beauty will be saved by merit! O heresy in fair, fit for these days! A giving hand, though foul, shall have fair praise. But come, the bow: now mercy goes to kill, And shooting well is then accounted ill. Thus will I save my credit in the shoot: Not wounding, pity would not let me do't; If wounding, then it was to show my skill, That more for praise than purpose meant to kill. And out of question so it is sometimes, Glory grows guilty of detested crimes, When, for fame's sake, for praise, an outward part, We bend to that the working of the heart; As I for praise alone now seek to spill The poor deer's blood, that my heart means no ill.

lines.speaker: boyet
lines.text: Do not curst wives hold that self-sovereignty Only for praise sake, when they strive to be Lords o'er their lords?

lines.speaker: princess
lines.text: Only for praise: and praise we may afford To any lady that subdues a lord.

lines.speaker: boyet
lines.text: Here comes a member of the commonwealth.
Enter COSTARD

lines.speaker: costard
lines.text: God dig-you-den all! Pray you, which is the head lady?

lines.speaker: princess
lines.text: Thou shalt know her, fellow, by the rest that have no heads.

lines.speaker: costard
lines.text: Which is the greatest lady, the highest?

lines.speaker: princess
lines.text: The thickest and the tallest.

lines.speaker: costard
lines.text: The thickest and the tallest! it is so; truth is truth. An your waist, mistress, were as slender as my wit, One o' these maids' girdles for your waist should be fit. Are not you the chief woman? you are the thickest here.

lines.speaker: princess
lines.text: What's your will, sir? what's your will?

lines.speaker: costard
lines.text: I have a letter from Monsieur Biron to one Lady Rosaline.

lines.speaker: princess
lines.text: O, thy letter, thy letter! he's a good friend of mine: Stand aside, good bearer. Boyet, you can carve; Break up this capon.

lines.speaker: boyet
lines.text: I am bound to serve. This letter is mistook, it importeth none here; It is writ to Jaquenetta.

lines.speaker: princess
lines.text: We will read it, I swear. Break the neck of the wax, and every one give ear.
Reads

lines.speaker: boyet
lines.text: 'By heaven, that thou art fair, is most infallible; true, that thou art beauteous; truth itself, that thou art lovely. More fairer than fair, beautiful than beauteous, truer than truth itself, have commiseration on thy heroical vassal! The magnanimous and most illustrate king Cophetua set eye upon the pernicious and indubitate beggar Zenelophon; and he it was that might rightly say, Veni, vidi, vici; which to annothanize in the vulgar,--O base and obscure vulgar!--videlicet, He came, saw, and overcame: he came, one; saw two; overcame, three. Who came? the king: why did he come? to see: why did he see? to overcome: to whom came he? to the beggar: what saw he? the beggar: who overcame he? the beggar. The conclusion is victory: on whose side? the king's. The captive is enriched: on whose side? the beggar's. The catastrophe is a nuptial: on whose side? the king's: no, on both in one, or one in both. I am the king; for so stands the comparison: thou the beggar; for so witnesseth thy lowliness. Shall I command thy love? I may: shall I enforce thy love? I could: shall I entreat thy love? I will. What shalt thou exchange for rags? robes; for tittles? titles; for thyself? me. Thus, expecting thy reply, I profane my lips on thy foot, my eyes on thy picture. and my heart on thy every part. Thine, in the dearest design of industry, DON ADRIANO DE ARMADO.' Thus dost thou hear the Nemean lion roar 'Gainst thee, thou lamb, that standest as his prey. Submissive fall his princely feet before, And he from forage will incline to play: But if thou strive, poor soul, what art thou then? Food for his rage, repasture for his den.

lines.speaker: princess
lines.text: What plume of feathers is he that indited this letter? What vane? what weathercock? did you ever hear better?

lines.speaker: boyet
lines.text: I am much deceived but I remember the style.

lines.speaker: princess
lines.text: Else your memory is bad, going o'er it erewhile.

lines.speaker: boyet
lines.text: This Armado is a Spaniard, that keeps here in court; A phantasime, a Monarcho, and one that makes sport To the prince and his bookmates.

lines.speaker: princess
lines.text: Thou fellow, a word: Who gave thee this letter?

lines.speaker: costard
lines.text: I told you; my lord.

lines.speaker: princess
lines.text: To whom shouldst thou give it?

lines.speaker: costard
lines.text: From my lord to my lady.

lines.speaker: princess
lines.text: From which lord to which lady?

lines.speaker: costard
lines.text: From my lord Biron, a good master of mine, To a lady of France that he call'd Rosaline.

lines.speaker: princess
lines.text: Thou hast mistaken his letter. Come, lords, away. Here, sweet, put up this: 'twill be thine another day.
To ROSALINE
Exeunt PRINCESS and train

lines.speaker: boyet
lines.text: Who is the suitor? who is the suitor?

lines.speaker: rosaline
lines.text: Shall I teach you to know?

lines.speaker: boyet
lines.text: Ay, my continent of beauty.

lines.speaker: rosaline
lines.text: Why, she that bears the bow. Finely put off!

lines.speaker: boyet
lines.text: My lady goes to kill horns; but, if thou marry, Hang me by the neck, if horns that year miscarry. Finely put on!

lines.speaker: rosaline
lines.text: Well, then, I am the shooter.

lines.speaker: boyet
lines.text: And who is your deer?

lines.speaker: rosaline
lines.text: If we choose by the horns, yourself come not near. Finely put on, indeed!

lines.speaker: maria
lines.text: You still wrangle with her, Boyet, and she strikes at the brow.

lines.speaker: boyet
lines.text: But she herself is hit lower: have I hit her now?

lines.speaker: rosaline
lines.text: Shall I come upon thee with an old saying, that was a man when King Pepin of France was a little boy, as touching the hit it?

lines.speaker: boyet
lines.text: So I may answer thee with one as old, that was a woman when Queen Guinover of Britain was a little wench, as touching the hit it.

lines.speaker: rosaline
lines.text: Thou canst not hit it, hit it, hit it, Thou canst not hit it, my good man.

lines.speaker: boyet
lines.text: An I cannot, cannot, cannot, An I cannot, another can.
Exeunt ROSALINE and KATHARINE

lines.speaker: costard
lines.text: By my troth, most pleasant: how both did fit it!

lines.speaker: maria
lines.text: A mark marvellous well shot, for they both did hit it.

lines.speaker: boyet
lines.text: A mark! O, mark but that mark! A mark, says my lady! Let the mark have a prick in't, to mete at, if it may be.

lines.speaker: maria
lines.text: Wide o' the bow hand! i' faith, your hand is out.

lines.speaker: costard
lines.text: Indeed, a' must shoot nearer, or he'll ne'er hit the clout.

lines.speaker: boyet
lines.text: An if my hand be out, then belike your hand is in.

lines.speaker: costard
lines.text: Then will she get the upshoot by cleaving the pin.

lines.speaker: maria
lines.text: Come, come, you talk greasily; your lips grow foul.

lines.speaker: costard
lines.text: She's too hard for you at pricks, sir: challenge her to bowl.

lines.speaker: boyet
lines.text: I fear too much rubbing. Good night, my good owl.
Exeunt BOYET and MARIA

lines.speaker: costard
lines.text: By my soul, a swain! a most simple clown! Lord, Lord, how the ladies and I have put him down! O' my troth, most sweet jests! most incony vulgar wit! When it comes so smoothly off, so obscenely, as it were, so fit. Armado o' th' one side,--O, a most dainty man! To see him walk before a lady and to bear her fan! To see him kiss his hand! and how most sweetly a' will swear! And his page o' t' other side, that handful of wit! Ah, heavens, it is a most pathetical nit! Sola, sola! LOVE'S LABOURS LOST
Shout within
Exit COSTARD, running
